bibl.author: Walt Whitman
bibl.title: Prose Writers of Germany
bibl.note: Transcribed from our own digital image of original manuscript.

div1.note: RESTORED BY J MACDONALD CO. NORWALK, CONN.
div1.p: Have filled this Vol. over twenty five years & read it off & on many hours, days & nights — this written Nov. 24 '88 in Mickle street Camden N J. W W

these card-photos Fred Gray NY. (whose father or rather F. G. from his father gave me the book)—I saw F during the war times & immediately after—but have lost track of him of later years (rem'ber Dr Russell, Charles Chauncy, Nat Bloom, Fritchy, the beer garden, the girls
div1.note: J.S.G. Frederick Schiller Gray from his father 12.th Aug. 1856.
div1.p: Aug 29, '62—F.S. Gray, (at Raeffele's, in 6th st) requested me to keep this book, as a memento of him. He goes in a few days on Gen. Smith's staff, down in the army in Virginia W.W.
Sept. 2. '62—Fred Gray (at Leotards) in 26th street—evening—(he is to go to‑morrow to the army.)

Battle of Antietam, Maryland, Sept. '62—F.S. has returned from his battle on a two days' furlough—I spent the evening with him (at Pfaff's & c)—He gave me a fearful account of the battle‑field at ½ past 9 that the night after following the engagement—He grcrossed it on duty.
Oct. 1. '62—I have called on Mrs Gray and heard that Fred is well and satisfied with his position & duties
FSG at on Gen Canbys staff, Jan Fst. &c Gs. — — at New Orleans June—Dec—186

figure.figDesc: full photo of F.S. Gray in uniform, by Brassart, Johnson and Williams

div1.p: Lieut. J.F.S. Gray Aide du camp, Maj. Genl. Wm. F. Smith's Division Franklin's Corps Army of the Potomac care of Genl. Williams A.A.G.

cit.quote: Die deutsche Nation ist nicht die ausgebildetste, nicht die reichste an Geistes– und Kunstprodukten, aber sie ist die aufgeklaerteste, weil sie die gruendlichste ist, sie ist eine philosophische Nation

bibl.title: The Dean of Harvard, Dead: Professor Frederick H. Hedge, of Harvard, Passes Away, Aged 85.
